section.name: preamble
section.information:
Welcome to the student toolkit for well-being. There's some minor information necessary to set you going so you can use your new app to soothe your mood, settle your stomach, and see a psych' whenever you like!
(This can all be tweaked in the settings.)
* The advice in this app is not written by professionals, but we're pretty knowledgeable!
Firstly, what should we call you? (If you're worried about privacy, now's the time to re-invent yourself. Otherwise, we'll remember you as 'guest'!)
name
login@university.ac.uk
You can use our interactive sections to store personal information. For this reason, you may want to password-protect them.

section.name: mainscroll
section.information: This is a triage service for your state of well-being. Take a look at our key sections of student-orientated information and interactive widgets to help you overcome your problems!
Sometimes a face-to-face can't be beaten. Take a look at your local resource center for well-being.

section.name: brain
section.information: Here's some information about the topic: Coming to university can be a stressful and overwhelming experience, but don’t despair! Understanding your feelings and how to cope is the first step to feeling like you are back on track. First let’s understand what depression is and how it can make you feel: • Extended periods of sadness • A feeling of hopelessness, • Lack of motivation and self-belief. • Feeling of fatigue • Insomnia The severity of these feeling can vary between students. For some these symptoms can subside over time, however, it is always worth being aware of how you can cope and the advice you can seek.

• Maintain a positive attitude. Try replacing negative thought with positive ones. • Keep to a routine and plan your days. Having structure will make you feel more at ease. • Remember, you are not the only one who feels this way, you are not alone. Consider reaching out to those close to you such as family and friends. • Use our app to book an appointment with your local counselling service.
Keep track of the things that make you happy:
And throw away the thoughts that don't...

section.name: heart
section.information: Anxiety often happens when we experience an uncomfortable, unusual or stressful situation. Physical feelings that may trigger included: sweating, an increase heart rate, an inability to breathe and panic attacks. Anxiety also affects us mentally due to the stain our bodies are put under. We may worry a lot, which resulting in a change of our behaviour towards others. We may feel overwhelmed and overcome by these feelings of anxiety and find ourselves acting out of character in situation. Also, some long term effects such may occur such as sleeping problems and depression. Situations where anxiety is common: 1 - Day before the exam 2 - Sitting in an exam room 3 - Going away from home (e.g. studying abroad) 4 - Going to a hospital Examples of what might causes of anxiety: 1 - Past experiences 2 - A drastic change 3 - Genetics 4 - New Experiences

Try to do some exercises to reduce stress for example such jogging, walking or swimming Stay relaxed by clearing your mind or listening to music, relaxation is one of the keys to this problem. Try to live a healthy lifestyle with a good diet Remember, you are not alone in this world sharing your problem with your friends and family also could also help you If you don't feel like the normal you after following some of the tips listed above, why not consider asking for help? Below are some places you can contact for a little extra help.
Breathe in and count to 2, These feelings will pass, Breathe out, Concentrate on your breathing
Follow the steps above when you are feeling stressed.

section.name: liver
section.information: Alcohol consumption for many students is a big part of university life, however it is important to remember the impact it can have on your health and studies! Excess consumption can have many consequences including the impairment of motor skills, harm to interpersonal relationships and along side badly affecting your studies. Peer pressure is often a large factor in student drinking and substance abuse, so remember it is okay to say no!
Know your limits Keep track of how many units you have Remember, it’s okay to say no! Always have plans to get home after drinking
Beer,Cider,Wine,Spirit,Alcopop,Sours,Other
Pint,Half Pint,Single Measure,Double Measure,Treble Measure,Large Wine Glass,Small Wine Glass,Other
You haven't had anything alcoholic yet. Abstaining is totally fine!
You're doing okay! Remember, it's not about the drink...
Be wary, you're almost over the government guidelines for alcohol consumption (surprising, huh?).
At this point, you should start slowing down. Remember to throw some water in the mix.
After this point, you may start feeling nauseous, and your decision-making skills may be impaired.
You have drunk a dangerous amount of alcohol. Any more can potentially cause longer lasting ailments.
It's time to go home, or possibly to the hospital.
This is over the recommended daily allowance.

section.name: preamble
section.information:
Bienvenido a la caja de herramientas del estudiante para el bienestar. Hay un poco de información de menor importancia necesaria para que te deja ir para que pueda utilizar su nueva aplicación para calmar su estado de ánimo, resolver su estómago, y ver un Psych 'siempre que lo desee!
(Todo esto puede ser ajustado en la configuración.)
* El consejo en esta aplicación no es escrito por profesionales, pero estamos bastante bien!
En primer lugar, ¿qué debemos llamar? (Si usted está preocupado acerca de la privacidad, ahora es el momento de reinventar a sí mismo. De lo contrario, le recordamos como "invitado"!)
nombre
login@university.ac.uk
Puede utilizar nuestras secciones interactivas para almacenar información personal. Por esta razón, es posible que desee proteger con contraseña ellas.

section.name: mainscroll
section.information: Este es un servicio de triaje para su estado de bienestar. Echar un vistazo a nuestras secciones clave de información centrado en el estudiante y widgets interactivos para ayudarle a superar sus problemas!
A veces una cara a cara no puede ser mejor. Echar un vistazo a su centro local de recursos para el bienestar.

section.name: brain
section.information: He aquí alguna información sobre el tema: El venir a la universidad puede ser una experiencia estresante y abrumadora, pero no se desespere! La comprensión de sus sentimientos y la forma de hacer frente es el primer paso para sentirse como si estuviera de nuevo en marcha. En primer lugar vamos a entender qué es la depresión y cómo se puede hacer que se sienta: • Los períodos prolongados de tristeza • Un sentimiento de desesperanza, • La falta de motivación y confianza en sí mismo. • Sensación de fatiga • insomnio La gravedad de estos sensación puede variar entre estudiantes. Para algunos de estos síntomas pueden desaparecer con el tiempo, sin embargo, es siempre vale la pena estar al tanto de cómo se puede hacer frente y el consejo que usted puede buscar.

• Maintain a positive attitude. Try replacing negative thought with positive ones. • Keep to a routine and plan your days. Having structure will make you feel more at ease. • Remember, you are not the only one who feels this way, you are not alone. Consider reaching out to those close to you such as family and friends. • Use our app to book an appointment with your local counselling service.
Keep track of the things that make you happy:
And throw away the thoughts that don't...

Below are some places you can contact for a little extra help.
Breathe in and count to 2, These feelings will pass, Breathe out, Concentrate on your breathing
Follow the steps above when you are feeling stressed.
